data.title: Higher Education Systems and Institutions, Spain
data.meta_description: 'Higher Education Systems and Institutions, Spain' published in 'Encyclopedia of International Higher Education Systems and Institutions'
data.text:
Spain, whose official name is the Kingdom of Spain, is located on the Iberian Peninsula in southwestern Europe, with two large archipelagos, the Balearic Islands in the Mediterranean Sea and the Canary Islands in front of the Atlantic coast of North Africa. It is the only European country with a border with Africa.

A member of the European Union (EU) since 1986, Spain is a parliamentary democracy under a constitutional monarchy. It is a developed country being the fifth strongest EU economy by GDP. With more than 46 million inhabitants, Spain is organized into 17 Autonomous Communities and 2 autonomous cities in North Africa: Ceuta and Melilla.

Historical Development of the Higher Education System

The modernization of the Spanish universities started in 1983 with the Law of University Reform (LRU) introducing major changes in the admission system, selection of teachers, and reorganization of the main university governing bodies.
